html.p: The following is a summary of the reading from the textbook to give you an idea of what is expected to know before coming to class. It does not replace reading the textbook.

Resistance depends both on the geometry of the wire and on the particular material from which the wire is made.The same is true of fluids. Molasses experiences more resistance than water when flowing through a similar pipe. Some of the resistance comes from the geometry of the pipe, and some comes from the different properties of molasses and water.

It is helpful to separate the geometry from the material property. For a cylindrical conductor the effects of the geometry are what your intuition expects: the longer the cylinder the larger the resistance; the larger the cross sectional area of the cylinder, the smaller the resistance. The resistance [mathjaxinline]R[/mathjaxinline] turns out to be proportional to the length [mathjaxinline]\ell[/mathjaxinline] of the conductor and inversely proportional to its cross sectional area [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline], and we can write

where the constant of proportionality [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline] is called the “resistivity" of the conducting material. The resistivity is a property of the material of which the conductor is made; its SI units are ohm-meters.

html.p: You will often see references to conductivity [mathjaxinline]\sigma[/mathjaxinline]. Conductivity is the reciprocal of resistivity:

and its SI units are siemens/meter abbreviated S/m. The historical name for conductivity was the mho/m. A mho and a siemens are the same thing, but “siemens" is coming to be used more than“mho"; SI is not whimsical.
